introduction.title: Triangle Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Triangle technique is one of the most fundamental designs in flower arrangement. It creates a stable, balanced composition that's pleasing to the eye.
keyPoints: Creates a triangular shape with varying heights
Establishes harmony and balance in arrangements
Works well for formal displays and traditional settings
Often uses odd numbers of flowers for better balance
introduction.history: This technique has roots in Japanese Ikebana and Western classical arrangements. It's considered a foundational skill for all flower arranging.

pages.content: Welcome to the Triangle technique! 💐 This classic design creates stability and harmony in your arrangement. Let's start this exciting journey together!

pages.instructions: Drag the flowers to create the first step of a triangle arrangement. Place the tallest stem in the center back.
pages.feedback: Great! You've set up the basic triangle structure. The tallest stem at the back creates the apex of your triangle.

pages.content: Excellent! Now let's continue building our triangle. The triangle technique uses three main points to create a triangular shape. Place your tallest stem at the back center as the apex.
Next, place medium height stems at the sides to form the width of your triangle. These should be slightly shorter than your center stem to create a natural slope.

pages.instructions: Click on the areas where you should place your medium-height stems to form the triangle's sides.

hotspots.feedback: Perfect! This creates the left side of your triangle.
Excellent! This completes the right side of your triangle.

pages.question: What shape should your arrangement form when using the triangle technique?
options: A perfect circle ⭕
A triangle with the tallest stem in the center 🔺
A square with equal height stems ⬜
A random assortment with no particular shape 🔄
pages.explanation: The triangle technique forms a triangular shape with the tallest stem at the back center (apex) and shorter stems on the sides, creating a three-dimensional triangular form.

pages.content: Now, fill in the remaining spaces with shorter stems and foliage to complete your triangular arrangement. This creates depth, fullness, and visual interest!

pages.instructions: Choose complementary colors for your triangle arrangement. Select colors that create harmony.

feedback.positive: Beautiful choice! These colors will create a harmonious triangle arrangement.
feedback.negative: These colors might clash a bit. Try a different combination for better harmony.

pages.question: What is the last step in creating a triangle arrangement?
options: Add more tall stems to the center 🌷
Remove all foliage 🚫
Fill in spaces with shorter stems and foliage 🌿
Create a second triangle upside down 🔻
pages.explanation: The final step is to fill in the spaces with shorter stems and foliage to create depth and fullness in your arrangement, completing the triangular shape.

introduction.title: Auxiliary Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Auxiliary technique focuses on enhancing primary focal flowers with complementary elements that add texture, depth, and visual interest.
keyPoints: Uses supporting flowers and foliage to complement focal blooms
Creates layers of visual interest and texture
Establishes rhythm and movement in arrangements
Adds depth and dimension to flat arrangements
introduction.history: This technique is widely used in European freestyle arrangements and contemporary designs. It emphasizes creativity and personal expression.

pages.content: Welcome to the Auxiliary technique! ✨ This approach focuses on adding supporting elements to enhance your main flowers, creating texture and visual interest.

pages.instructions: Adjust the slider to see how different amounts of auxiliary elements affect your arrangement.
pages.feedback: Notice how the character of the arrangement changes with different amounts of auxiliary elements. Finding the right balance is key!

pages.content: Begin by placing your focal flowers - these are typically larger, more colorful blooms that draw the eye and serve as the stars of your arrangement.

pages.instructions: Click on the image to identify where focal flowers should be placed in this arrangement.

hotspots.feedback: Perfect! Focal flowers should be prominent and draw attention.
Good choice! This is an excellent spot for a secondary focal point.

pages.content: Now add auxiliary elements like smaller flowers, buds, and textural elements around your focal flowers. These support and enhance the main blooms while adding depth and interest.

pages.instructions: Match each auxiliary element with its best use in an arrangement.
pages.feedback: Excellent matching! Understanding the purpose of different auxiliary elements helps you create more dynamic arrangements.

pages.question: What is the primary purpose of auxiliary elements in flower arrangement?
options: To replace the main flowers 🔄
To support and enhance the focal flowers ✨
To make the arrangement taller 📏
To reduce the cost of the arrangement 💰
pages.explanation: Auxiliary elements support and enhance the focal flowers by adding texture, depth, and visual interest to the arrangement while allowing the main blooms to shine.

introduction.title: Linear Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Linear technique creates modern, minimalist arrangements with strong directional lines and clean composition.
keyPoints: Emphasizes clean, straight lines and angles
Uses minimal materials for maximum impact
Focuses on negative space as much as the flowers
introduction.history: This approach gained popularity in mid-century modern design and continues to be favored in contemporary and minimalist settings.

pages.content: Welcome to the Linear technique! 📏 This modern approach creates clean, contemporary arrangements with strong lines and minimal elements. Perfect for modern spaces!

pages.instructions: Draw lines to show how you would position stems in a linear arrangement.
pages.feedback: Great job! Linear arrangements use clean, deliberate lines to create visual impact with minimal elements.

pages.content: Start by selecting long, straight stems like gladiolus, snapdragons, or delphinium. These create the primary lines in your arrangement and establish the overall structure.

pages.instructions: Sort these flowers from most suitable to least suitable for linear arrangements.
pages.feedback: Perfect! Long, straight stems are ideal for linear arrangements, while round, full blooms are better suited for other styles.

pages.content: Position your stems at various angles to create interesting linear patterns. Focus on creating vertical, horizontal, or diagonal lines that guide the eye through the arrangement.

pages.question: Which flowers are best suited for linear arrangements?
options: Round, full blooms like peonies 🌺
Long, straight stems like gladiolus and snapdragons 📏
Fluffy flowers like hydrangeas ☁️
Small clustered flowers like baby's breath ✨
pages.explanation: Long, straight stems like gladiolus and snapdragons are ideal for linear arrangements because they naturally create strong, clean lines that define this style.

pages.instructions: Slide to see the transformation from unorganized stems to a structured linear arrangement.
pages.feedback: See how organizing stems with intention creates a striking linear composition? The arrangement becomes more impactful and modern.

introduction.title: Foliage Technique Basics
introduction.description: The Foliage technique focuses on leaves, branches, and greenery as the primary design elements rather than flowers.
keyPoints: Celebrates the beauty and variety of leaves and stems
Creates textural contrast through different leaf shapes
Uses varying shades of green for subtle color variation
Creates long-lasting arrangements that don't rely on blooms
introduction.history: This technique has roots in Japanese Ikebana and has gained popularity with the rise of sustainable and minimalist design approaches.

pages.content: Welcome to the Foliage technique! 🌿 This approach celebrates greenery as the star of the arrangement rather than just as a background for flowers. Let's explore the beauty of leaves!

pages.instructions: Move the spotlight over the image to examine different textures and types of foliage in this arrangement.

infoPoints.text: Large monstera leaves create bold structure 🌴
Eucalyptus provides movement and airy quality 🌳

pages.content: Begin by selecting a variety of foliage with different shapes, textures, and shades of green. Consider ferns, eucalyptus, ivy, monstera leaves, and other interesting greens.

pages.instructions: Create a texture palette for your foliage arrangement. Select leaves with complementary textures.
pages.feedback: Beautiful combination! Mixing different textures creates visual interest even without flowers.

pages.content: Create a framework with larger leaves first, then fill in with smaller or more delicate foliage. Focus on creating contrast between different leaf shapes and textures for a dynamic arrangement.

pages.question: What is the primary focus in a foliage arrangement?
options: Bright, colorful flowers 🌸
Greenery and leaves of various textures and shapes 🌿
Height and size of the arrangement 📏
Expensive, exotic blooms 💰
pages.explanation: In a foliage arrangement, the primary focus is on greenery and leaves of various textures and shapes, with little or no flowers. The beauty comes from the diversity of foliage.

pages.instructions: Select different shades of green to create a monochromatic foliage arrangement.

feedback.positive: Beautiful selection! These varying shades of green will create depth and interest in your foliage arrangement.
feedback.negative: Try selecting more varied shades of green to create depth in your arrangement.
